title: Why are really expensive pens (Sheaffer, Caran d'Ache, etc.) so heavy? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all, the premise of the question is not entirely true. Many expensive pens are made with plastic or with premium materials such as celluloid or ebonite, which are very light in the hand. For various reasons, a majority of the premium offerings from established pen manufacturers do not incorporate much metal as a primary structural material, and most expensive pens do not go far over 25 to 30 grams. (For reference, a modern Montblanc 149 with brass piston threads is around 32 grams.) For one, it's simply hard to make a heavy pen that's well balanced and comfortable in the hand for long writing sessions. Conversely, you can find cheap Chinese pens with brass or stainless steel construction that are quite heavy, in the 25-gram range or more. Some of these are reasonably good beginner fountain pens, but many of the heavy Chinese pens are tacky and rather unbalanced. Now, it is true that many expensive pens incorporate a significant amount of metal. As others have stated, the added weight can add a feeling of heft, substance, and refinement. That is one pen design "paradigm" that you can find, but weight is not a defining characteristic of all or even most expensive fountain pens. Even if a maker is set out to design a rather hefty pen, at some point, it becomes impractical to add much more weight without adversely affecting balance, and I'm sure the marginal perception of prestige or value decreases significantly once you reach 30-gram territory. My heaviest pen is probably the all-metal Lamy Dialog 3. While it's a treat to hold in the hand for a few light notes or sketches, at almost 50 grams, it's quite tiring to use all day. But most of my pens are considerably lighter. I doubt that any of my most expensive dozen or so pens exceed 20 grams or so.
